comments.commentBody: Sayonara, adios, Coughlin and Gilbride, good riddance.  If you're still around next year, Mr. Reese, find a real O coordinator.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
I can't say anything... everything negative that was said about this team earlier is deserved.

Moving on.

There are a tremendous number myths about health care today in the US. These are further exacerbated by the failure of many citizens, including many commenting on this article, to realize what is actually in the Obamacare legislative package. Not very many people, including me, have read it. Let me expose some of these myths based on what I have read:

1. There is a false perception that 40 million uninsured US citizens receive no health care. A portion of these can afford insurance but elect to self insure and pay for their medical services.
There are free medical services in all major cities for those below a certain income level. (For example, In Atlanta anyone can go to Grady Memorial were services are free for anyone up to 3 times the poverty level. For a couple with two children, this income cap is over $60,000 and nobody is checking. You can even be here illegally and qualify! Fulton county, where I live, pays Grady $40 million a year for this service. No one is suggesting that this goes away under Obamacare.) There are undoubtedly needy people who need help but it is nowhere near the 40 million number.

2. People, including illegal aliens in some states, under the poverty level qualify for Medicaid. Medicaid costs on average $7,500 per recipient per year split between the states and the federal government. Yet Obamacare forecasts less than half this amount is required for the uninsured program. If Obamacare can do it for this much less, why not start with the 40 million Medicaid recipients where we are already spending over $300 billion per year and have a administrative staff in place?

3. Obamacare presumes that all 40 million uninsured will sign up. After all, their cost is limited to 8% of thetir income, Uncle Sam pays the rest. Also, they will have to pay $750 pr year if they do not sign up and get nothing. Wait, a minute. If a person makes $20,000 per year they will have to spend $1,600 for coverage versus paying $750 for nothing. If they make more, the impact is worse. Why won't they wait until they really need it? They can then go to Grady or sign up since there is no denial for a preexisting condition.

4. Obamacare is self funded as reflected by the Congressional budget office. First, the Congressional budget office is not allowed to question any assumptions or develop any anternative projections. They simply verify the numbers based on the assumptions provided.
Obamacare projects less than half the current costs per recipient for any other federal health care program over a future 10 year period. Historic health care inflation rates are over 6% per year on average. This is not feasible.

There is a real need for reform in the current health care system. We should separate the reforms from covering the uninsured and focus on real numbers and feasible improvements.
A trip to the "Wembley of the Fens" - The Traderecruitment Stadium - a.k.a. The Abbey Stadium on Newmarket Road whenever the Mighty U's are playing has never failed to lift my spirits...

Eli has had his moments but on balance he is not a good QB.  He single handedly killed them tonight with 4 turnovers.  That unforced fumble in the 4th was particularly ridiculous.  Does he suffer from some sort of musculoskeletal defect?
I would just say: get out and support the game every time you can. That's all.

not much time to clean up their act
toomany mental mistakes-that 15 yard on the last kickoff was inexcusable
thankfully no dominant team out there to be afraid of
this luck can't last all the way to the super bowl
I wonder if they had lost one of these games if they would feel more urgency to play smarter and with less mistakes

How heartwarming to learn that it's still possible to re-enact 'Les Misérables' a hundred fifty years after the fact. Is there also a market for human teeth to be used in dentures?

How about a market for women's flesh?

In places where vultures can turn a quick profit off the desperation of those hit by economic blight, hair isn't the only body part to become a commodity. Plus ça change...

What a terrific theme! Very nicely done, as Jim described at the top. I don't thing the mix of two nationalities and two cities is a consistency problem (though three of one, and one of the other would have been). In any case, there were other elements tying together the theme. Kudos to David Poole on a nifty puzzle.

Kudos to Jim for the paradox from Zeno, which I got a kick out of, even if others might not have. I would warn anyone racing Dan, if the game is crosswords, to get a really big head start.
While North Americans tend to call them "SUVs", "Sport Ute" is the standard term everywhere else in the English-speaking world.

This was a safe hiring.
Why is it that until today, all the media coverage portrayed Collins as a vanilla choice, but suddenly we find that he's "feisty and intense?"
Front-office spin, perhaps, to ease the fans' sting at not getting Wally?
I'm still trying to read Jim's blog entry.  Every time my reading catches up to his writing, he moves ahead to the next sentence, and I can never catch up completely, so I don't know how it ends.
That Reynaldo chick currently has the fifth fastest time, with 2:35.  People who know her will vouch that that is nothing special, an everyday thing.

<- Also missed the comeback. Beamed out after the pick at 2:11. Got a text from my brother "Are you kiddin' me?", assumed he meant blowing a 23 - 7 lead at home. Didn't find out til about 10 PM that we had actually come back to win.

Easy enough to blame Greene, and he is to blame for failing to take care of the ball. He is not to blame for the tidal wave of momentum which swamped the defense. There is no excuse for the meltdown they suffered in the ensuing two Houston drives. Greene didn't blow a coverage, he didn't miss tackles, he didn't bend and finally break against the Texan's furious onslaught.

Greene is a fine, capable running back who may one day be special. He still forgets to plow ahead in some cases and tries to hard for the extra yard. He needs to learn to lower his body, hit somebody, and drive until he's on the ground. Twisting and turning are not his thing. He lost the ball while standing straight up.

The offense has now rescued the defense for four games in a row. The last three of those, the defense has surrendered fourth quarter leads. Rex can crow all he wants about where he expects to be at the end of the season, and it may even be true, but today this defense lacks an identity, other than "good til it matters."

I need to learn to stick around til the final gun.

CANADIAN BACON, ITALIAN BREAD and BOSTON LETTUCE are all complete, stand alone place-food phrases.  MONTEREY JACK isn't. CHEESE (or maybe MACKEREL) needs to be added to make it a complete place-food phrase.

wouah ! i'm late this time - got a session of lagoon cleaning, divers, snorkelers and kayakers alltogether - and thought of letting it pass. But i don't regret my reading finally.
Honestly it's too hot for me, i"ll let you guys fighting on the subject. For me, it was not an easy one cause i started with only 2! (Escoffier and Imported) and two others ( Noodles and Epicure). I feel amazed by how "thirtyam" # 12 may have got Alphabet - one of the tricky ones - on the first pass. I allways have so much to fight on - this time the included proposition "our father seemed to imply" , and some time before i put a dot after British, searching for a Britsh specialty, which was frankly stupid !! - that i can't agree with the "theming clues" complainers.
Where are you Tudor ? Got a St Laurent cleaning session ?
Ellie May should ask Chase Utley how to slide.
We have a wonderful, playful, alert and active wire fox terrier.  His nickname (not his name) is Skeezicks.  I remember the name from the comic strip.

Daisy, Daisy,
Give me your answer do
I'm half crazy,
All for the love of you
It won't be a stylish marriage
I can't afford a carriage
But you'll look sweet
Upon the seat
Of a bicycle built (4,2)
Outerwear for January. (650, down)
Put Nick Fairley on the opposing defense.

I run an agency that provides care for people with autism, and I have also studied the Tractatus (and the Philosophical Investigations, and some of Wittgenstein's other works).

I don't see any links between autistic behavior and Wittgenstein's. The fact that he talks about metalanguage being meaningless is rooted in the mistaken belief that you can't talk about a language using that language (see Paul Feyerabend's essay on Wittgenstein). There is nothing autistic about it. The behavior of people with autism has nothing to do with Wittgenstien's philosophical work. For a better explanation of his outlook and behavior, see the Harper's article on Wittgenstein published a year or two ago.

I invite you to consider what Wittgenstein would think of people poring over his words and trying to eke out their meanings.

He regarded such a prospect with absolute horror.

As a psychologist who was a philosophy major (with a lot of interest in Wittgenstein in fact) I find this article frustrating.

Prof. Martin clearly does not understand autism, as many other comments have pointed out.

I am surprised since I thought philosophy is a training in the dangers of partial knowledge, especially when generalized very broadly as is done in this article.

This article really muddies the water so that it appears deep.   What's next in the way of inane exegetical accounts of Wittgenstein? Perhaps todays pedants will offer new insights yet with the newly popular data mining techniques that seem to be all the rage in today's liberal arts branch of academia .  Here though, Wittgenstein deserves better than being subjected to amateur psychological analysis where he is outfitted with the fashionable label of being autistic to explain his odd behavior.  Wittgenstein would have recoiled at such shabby thinking, especially considering the medical difficulty of diagnosing autism in the first place.
